comment.author: 73862327@N00
comment._content:
note the small chunks of coal they have stuffed their noses with.

trapped possums are soooooo stinky.

comment.author: 23418493@N08
comment._content: Those are possums, not opossums. They are native to Australia, New Guinea and now native to New Zealand. They are considered a pest species in Australia and New Zealand. The photo must have been taken in Australia.

comment.author: 73862327@N00
comment._content: The words were synonymous until the 30s and "opossum" is still heard today. Given the source, I think it's likely this image is from NZ.

comment.author: 24202979@N06
comment._content: The image is from New Zealand, as xurizaemon rightly points out. Possums are not "now native to New Zealand", they are an introduced species and very much a pest there, being selective eaters which will happily munch their favourite tree to death before moving onto the next. These are brushtail possums and are protected throughout mainland Australia (and partially protected in Tasmania). So, while some in Australia might consider the brushtail possum a pest, I wouldn't take Mary Cummins' word for it and start trapping 'em willy nilly. Get caught with a bag of brushtails like this in Aus, and you'll have the some explaining to do to the Parks and Wildlife Service.
